intro: Lepidaploa arborescens, commonly known as the tree-like lepidaploa, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. It is a shrub or small tree native to South America, particularly found in regions of Argentina and Chile. The plant features compound leaves with serrated margins and produces small, white to pale yellow flowers in clustered umbels. Its fruit is a dry, two-lobed schizocarp that splits into two one-seeded segments upon maturity. Lepidaploa arborescens is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has some traditional medicinal uses in local communities.
